claim: Cancer can cause excess adrenaline production.

supporting.text: Certain tumors, such as pheochromocytomas, are known to secrete excessive adrenaline and related hormones, leading to elevated levels in the body.

attacks.text: Certain tumors, such as pheochromocytomas, are known to secrete excessive adrenaline and related hormones, leading to elevated levels in the body.
Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors, accounting for less than 0.2% of all cancers, so they are not representative of most cancer cases.
Even though pheochromocytomas are rare, they are a well-documented and definitive example of cancers causing excess adrenaline production, supporting the general claim.
Many common cancers (e.g., lung, breast, or colon cancer) do not typically cause excess adrenaline production, limiting the generality of the claim.
While common cancers may not directly secrete adrenaline, they can indirectly elevate stress hormones due to systemic effects like pain or hypoxia.

supporting.text: Neuroblastomas, a type of cancer originating in nerve tissue, can produce catecholamines, including adrenaline, as part of their metabolic activity.

attacks.text: Neuroblastomas, a type of cancer originating in nerve tissue, can produce catecholamines, including adrenaline, as part of their metabolic activity.
Neuroblastomas are rare, accounting for only 6% of childhood cancers, making them an exception rather than a representative case of cancer causing excess adrenaline.
Even though neuroblastomas are rare, they are a well-documented example of cancers directly causing excess adrenaline production, supporting the general claim.
Most common cancers (e.g., lung, breast, prostate) do not directly produce adrenaline, limiting the generalizability of the claim.
While most cancers do not produce adrenaline, the claim does not specify frequency or commonality, only possibility, which neuroblastomas confirm.

supporting.text: Metastatic cancers affecting the adrenal glands can disrupt normal hormone regulation, resulting in overproduction of adrenaline.

attacks.text: Metastatic cancers affecting the adrenal glands can disrupt normal hormone regulation, resulting in overproduction of adrenaline.
Most cancers do not metastasize to the adrenal glands, making this an uncommon cause of excess adrenaline production.
Even when cancers metastasize to the adrenal glands, they often destroy adrenal tissue rather than causing overproduction of hormones.
Non-cancerous conditions like pheochromocytoma are far more common causes of excess adrenaline production than metastatic cancers.
Pheochromocytomas are rare, and metastatic cancers to the adrenals, while uncommon, still represent a significant subset of cases with excess adrenaline.

supporting.text: Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with some cancers can stimulate the adrenal glands to release excessive adrenaline as part of an abnormal immune response.

attacks.text: Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with some cancers can stimulate the adrenal glands to release excessive adrenaline as part of an abnormal immune response.
Paraneoplastic syndromes are rare, occurring in less than 1% of cancer patients, making this mechanism an unlikely general explanation for excess adrenaline production in cancer.
Even though rare, paraneoplastic syndromes are well-documented in medical literature, and their impact on adrenal function is clinically significant when they do occur.
Excess adrenaline in cancer patients is more commonly caused by stress, pain, or tumor-induced hypoxia rather than paraneoplastic syndromes.
While stress and hypoxia are common causes, paraneoplastic syndromes represent a distinct and direct pathological mechanism for adrenaline overproduction in specific cancer cases.

supporting.text: Small cell lung cancer has been documented to produce ectopic hormones, including adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which can indirectly increase adrenaline secretion.

attacks.text: Small cell lung cancer has been documented to produce ectopic hormones, including adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which can indirectly increase adrenaline secretion.
Not all small cell lung cancers produce ectopic hormones, and even those that do may not always secrete ACTH in sufficient quantities to significantly increase adrenaline levels.
Studies show that ACTH secretion in small cell lung cancer is relatively common, with approximately 50% of cases exhibiting some level of ectopic hormone production.
Increased adrenaline secretion due to ACTH is often transient and may not lead to clinically significant symptoms or long-term effects.
Even transient increases in adrenaline can have measurable physiological impacts, such as elevated heart rate and blood pressure, which are clinically relevant.
